comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: I wonder if these could have been the "oregon girls" mentioned in second article from NYT (June 13, 1912) in query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9B02E7DE113AE633A... Nine girls from Oregon were trying to see the sights of New York in two days before going on to Washington, DC, where a visit to the president was planned. They were daughters of well-to-do farmers from different regions of the state on a chaperoned trip. A similar trip was made the next year too. See query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9A02E5DF153FE633A... from June 18, 1913. The participants for this trip were teachers.

comment.author: 59290828@N03
comment._content: This is almost certainly the July 1913 excursion. The 1912 trip was intended to include a girl from each of Oregon's 36 counties; the latter trip included only Laura M. Dawson, Harney County, Ore.; Belle C. Nelson, Vernonia, Oregon; Mable Morrison, Colfax, Wash.; Sara Mosley, Bickleton, Wash.; May Springer, Walla Walla, Wash.; Ethel Hutchcroft, Yamhill, Ore.; Nett R. Drew, Klamath Falls, Ore.; Marvel Ramey, Nez Perce, Idaho; Mrs. G. L. Barkley, Ellensburg, Wash., and organizer Phil S. Bates, Portland. The 1913 party is recorded as having stayed at the Martha Washington Hotel: oregonnews.uoregon.edu/lccn/sn96088246/1913-07-12/ed-1/se...

comment.author: 59290828@N03
comment._content: I found a citation that the 1912 party included 40 people, but haven't found a roster like that for 1913.

comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: This Ethel Hutchcroft (1893-1966; Mrs. Ernest Groocock) of Yamhill County OR would have been 20 in 1913: www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=90687842

comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: Found this: WESTERN GIRLS WANT TO BORROW LIBERTY BELL New York's Horse Cars and Slit Skirts Set Their Tongues Wagging Fast New York Sun, 18 June 1913, p. 6 "Eight girls from Washington, Oregon, and Idaho arrived in New York yesterday on their way to Philadelphia, where they will try to borrow the Liberty Bell for the Panama Canal Exposition in San Francisco. They were not favorably impressed with New York. "'I had come to the biggest city in the country to see my first horse car,' said Miss Marvel Ramey of Nez Perce, Idaho, whose red cheeks and sturdy figure proclaimed her Western origin. 'I never saw such poor street car service anyway. And the way the men push! But when you look at the poor things and how pale and hollow eyed they are you know they need the seats worse than you do and you would be ashamed to take one. "'I didn't look at the women's faces on Fifth avenue. Their clothes were beautiful.' "'I thought they were dreadful,' said Mrs. G. L. Barkley, Superintendent of Schools in Kittias county, Washington, who is chaperoning the expedition. 'Why, I saw a woman as old as I am and I could see through the slit in her skirt.' "She added that girls who go West can find plenty of husbands. 'But,' she said, 'our young men are wise. They are more apt to ask whether a girl can make good bred than whether she can wear a slit skirt effectively.'"

comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: "Mrs. G. L. Barkley" was Geneva Lincoln Barkley (1869-1932--the first name is sometimes spelled "Genevra"), Superintendent of Public Instruction for Kittitas County, Washington; married to Wooster Nathaniel Barkley (1870-1936); so she would have been 44 in 1913. www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GSln=Barkle...; news.google.com/newspapers?id=-csrAAAAIBAJ&sjid=cIQFA... (I notice the current city manager in Ellensburg is Ted Barkley, might be kin.)

comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: The "Nett R. Drew" in Ben Truwe's roster must be Nett Drew Peterson (1884-1957), who was a school principal before she married. She would have been 29 in 1913. She married that same year, to Fred Peterson, who was a county school superintendent (like Mrs. Barkley) for decades. Here's Nett's gravesite, with her 1957 obituary: www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=33201212

comment.author: 11418107@N02
